subject: Re: [junit] Re: With out changing the excepted value in my code regularly
msgSnippet: ... It looks like your expected result only depends on the input; is that correct? If so, then I don t understand why you have a problem: each test defines a
messageBody:
p_thanuja82 wrote:
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "J. B.
> Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > p_thanuja82 wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > > Hi All,
> > >
> > > In my test case the excepted value will be changed frequently.
> > > so I have to change my excepted data each and every time in my
> code. I
> > > dont want to go in to my code and change the excepted data.
> > >
> > > Instead of doing this, I want to get the data with out changing
> > > it every time. Please suggest me any other methods with out
> changing
> > > the excepted data in my code.
> >
> > Why does your expected result change frequently? Does it depend on
> the
> > input or on some other dependency, like a database? Can you give
> me an
> > example of such a test?
> > --
> > J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca <http://www.jbrains.ca>
> > Your guide to software craftsmanship
> > JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> > 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
> >
>
> yes, it depends on the database. The excepted data will be changed
> when the it is updated. This updation will be update frequently.
>
> The below is my testcase please check it and suggest me

It looks like your expected result only depends on the input; is that
correct? If so, then I don't understand why you have a problem: each
test defines a different expected result for different input, which is
what I would expect. Nothing special here.

So does your expected result depend only on the input, or does it /also/
depend on the state of the database? If it depends on the state of the
database, why does that change? Do you change it, or does someone else
change it? Could you stop it from changing?
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
